question: Why should I use indentation? How do I indent correctly?
answer:
To keep a good overview. Code gets very long quickly and if you don't indent correctly you will find it really hard to keep track of which elements are inside which other elements and which opening and closing tags belong together.
Generally speaking you indent everything that's between an opening <...> and closing tag </...>.
An example might look like this:

<parent>
<first-child>some content</first-child>
<second-child>some content</second-child>
<third-child>some content</third-child>
</parent>

Notice how all three children are indented on the same level. That's because their closing tags are before the next opening tag. That's why they are also called siblings because they are all children of the same parents.
Just like in a real family children can become parents again. That's how we get multiple indentations:

<great_grandparent>
<grandparents1>
<parents1>
<child1>
<grandchild>some content</grandchild>
</child1>
<child2>
Some content
</child2>
</parents1>
<parents2>
Some content
</parents2>
</grandparents1>
<grandparents2>
Some content
</grandparents2>
</great_grandparent>

The grandparents are siblings, thus on the same level. The parents are all on the same level. The children are as well and so on.

question: What do I need comments for and how do I use them best?
answer: Commenting is a good way of making your code more readable for yourself and others. Either people who work with you, possible employers or yourself a few weeks after writing the original code, all these people will highly appreciate well commented code. In JavaScript you can use it to explain functionality. In CSS you can use it to separate your code into groups (for example you can put stylings for specific pages in groups seperated by comments). In HTML It is often times extremly useful to put comments behind every single closing div tag. When you use Bootstrap it is very likely you end up having 3 or more div closing tags in a row. To keep track of which opening tag they belong to it is a good idea to put a comment behind each one of them with a description of which opening tag they belong to.

question: What is the difference between classes and IDs and why/when do I use them?
answer:
All HTML elements can have a class and id attribute. Generally speaking can you name your classes and IDs what ever you want. It doesn't have any influence on your website whatsoever if a class or ID is called 'container', 'beer', 'i_like_trains' or 'padding'. It has only an influence on your layout if you change something in the CSS (but more about that in just a second).
The big difference between classes and IDs is that IDs are unique and each HTML element can only have a single ID. Also not two or more HTML elements can have an ID of the same name. They always have to bee different. Classes, however, can be used as often as you like. Any HTML element can have as many classes, just seperated by a space (e.g. <div class="container beer i_like_trains">), as you like. And you can use the same class on as many HTML elements as you like.
So what are classes and IDs for anyway?
With classes and IDs you can very easily address specific HTML elements. You can apply a class to an HTML element and then in your CSS with a dot infront of the class name you can define stylings for all HTML elements that have that particular class. So if you write .padding { padding: 20px; } in your CSS and apply the class 'padding' to several HTML elements all these elements will get a padding of 20px.
You can do the same thing with IDs, but since you can use IDs only once, people use classes more commonly for styling. IDs get interesting once you want to work with JavaScript or want to link to certain parts of your HTML page.

question: What is 'jumbotron' (Bootstrap)?
answer: 'jumbotron' is a predefined class in Bootstrap. It is a component used to catch the attention of your website's user. Generally people put a few lines like a welcome text and maybe a button in there. Do not wrap it around all content on your website! That's what a container could be used for.

question: What does 'container' do (Bootstrap)?
answer: 'container' is a predefined class in Bootstrap. Containers are needed if you want to make use of the Bootstrap Grid-System. That's why they usually house a big chunk of a pages content. In many cases one container per page is enough. They fill the full width of their parent element. Containers should not be nested inside each other.

question: How do I use Google Fonts?
answer: Admittedly Google Fonts are not very intuitive for beginners. With the filters to the right of their page you can filter the different fonts and look for one you like. Once you found one you click on the second of the three buttons at the bottom of the font (it has a little box with an arrow pointing to the right). This will bring you to a page where you can do final customizations of the font and what you might need. Then you scroll to the third step and cope the link tag. Now you can paste it inside the HTML file where you want to use the font before your other link tags that point to your CSS files. The fourth step will show you how to use the font inside your CSS after you embedded it in your HTML file.

question: My image is too big and messes up my whole layout.
answer:
You can style images with CSS just as any other HTML elements. The best way to go about it is to use a custom class for the image tag, maybe like this:
<img src="image.jpg" class="my_image" />
In your CSS you can then define the dimensions of your image.

question: How should I organize my CSS?
answer: Most websites use the same design throughout all pages (with a few custom elements on some pages). That's why it is generally a good idea to keep all your CSS in a single styles.css file (except for CSS coming from frameworks or plugins like bootstrap.css and normalize.css). This way you can define general styling and access that everywhere inside your website and don't have to repeat the same styling over and over again. Only if you are absolutely certain you will use a particular styling only on a single page, it makes sense to create a new CSS file. Otherwise you might seperate your CSS code into groups with comments (see also the section about comments on this page).

question: My layout is messed up and I don't know why! / My website has a white area on the right!
answer:
Bootstrap provides great classes to layout your website. If you use Bootstrap it is important that you follow its rules. You will find that you can do most of your layouting without writing a single line of CSS code.
Most mistakes happen because the grid system is not used correctly or messed up with custom CSS. Read the Bootstrap documentation about their grid system! You will see that you need to have a container(-fluid) if you want to use your grid. A row must be a direct child of a container and all your col- elements must be direct decendents of your row.
Also keep in mind that the grid system is there to structure your website into 12 columns. It is like the wooden frame of a painting. It's behind the actual painting to keep it stable but it's invisible for the user. If you want to change padding, margin, height, position or any other layouting styles do not change Bootstrap's grid-classes (.container(-fluid), .row, .col- etc.)! That will easily mess up your layout. Rather create a new div for example inside your div with the class .col-xs-12 and give it your own class (e.g. .padding-left). Then you can apply your own padding and positioning styles but don't damage the frame that's supposed to keep your website stable.

question: I have problems with positioning my elements! / My navigation is shifted and not full width!
answer: Keep your HTML code in the same order in which you want to display the content on your website. Code that's all the way at the top of the page should also be all the way at the top in your HTML code (e.g. a header or a navigation bar). Content that's all the way at the bottom (like a footer) should also be all the way at the bottom in your code. Also keep in mind to put something inside an element if it really belongs in there. For example a navigation bar is usually all the way at the top of the page and not part of the content you might keep inside Bootstrap's grid system.

question: Do I need the normalize.css and Boostrap?
answer: No. Boostrap has the normalize.css already included.

question: What is the difference between the CDN link to boostrap.css and the bootstrap.css file I downloaded and put in my project folder?
answer:
Both of the following two lines do the same thing:
<link href="https://maxcdn.bootstrapcdn.com/bootstrap/3.3.2/css/bootstrap.min.css" rel="stylesheet">
<link href="css/bootstrap.min.css" rel="stylesheet">
Both files contain exactly the same code. So never include both files in your HTML head. The first line is a link to the bootstrap.css file that lies on a different server somewhere online. It is faster to work with and can possibly lower load times for your user if he already accessed a website using Bootstrap before. The second link points to a local copy of the bootstrap.css file. Downloading the bootstrap.css allows you to be independent from other servers. Also you can customize the Bootstrap CSS and take out elements you don't need to save load time.

question: Some parts of my JavaScript don't seem to run correctly.
answer: Check the <head> of your website and make sure to put all your <script> tags below your <link> tags. JavaScript files always come at the bottom and all your CSS needs to be above them to make sure everything loads properly.

question: How do I test associated models?
answer:
When testing a model that belongs_to another model you have to remember creating the model it belongs to. You can create both in your 'before' block like this:

@product = Product.new(name: "boat", price 20)
@review = @product.reviews.build(rating: 4)

Now you will be able to access @review or even @review.product anywhere in your tests.

question: How do I test with my controllerst that use authentication with Devise?
answer:
You will have to add a few lines to your rails_helper or specs_helper file. This will enable you to use the 'sign_in' helper to sign in a user inside your 'before' block. The absolute simplest way this could look like is this (inside your describe ProductsController):

before do
@user = User.create(email: "max@mustermann.de", password: "12345678")
end

context "GET #index" do
before do
sign_in @user
get :index, id: @user.id
end
[...]

question: What do I need client side MVCs like Angular.js and Ember.js for?
answer:
This very website is built with Angular.js . Client side MVC frameworks allow your users to interact with your websites content dynamically without accessing any server side code.
You can also use it to store your websites content in a different place than you website design. This website for example keeps all questions and answers in a single JSON file. This makes it easy to edit content without having to worry about the layout.
